abstracts.cdata!:
The Bosnia-Herzegovina Mostar Water
            Supply and Sanitation Project had a satisfactory outcome,
            likely sustainability, high institutional development
            impact, and overall satisfactory Bank and Borrower
            performances. Lesson One: Closely project objectives to
            country aspirations during project preparation and to the
            capacity of the government and agency to implement them.
            Lesson Two: Increase the chances of a satisfactory outcome
            and of sustainable benefits by having a sustained
            relationship with a city. The continuous and widespread
            support of the rebuilding of the city of Mostar built trust
            in the Bank as a development partner and fostered acceptance
            of Bank advice and assistance. Lesson Three: Small borrowers
            pay a relatively large cost to comply with the Bank's
            fiduciary requirements for Financial Management Systems
            (FMS). Costs mandated under the Bank's fiduciary FMS
            requirements should be related to the economic capacity of
            the Borrower, the size of the project and the value gained.
            Despite improvements in the Bank's FMS requirements
            since project preparation, they continue to be both costly
            and unrelated to client value. Lesson Four: The Project
            showed the virtues of limiting the externally contracted
            consultancy to that which the Mostar Water and Sewerage
            Utility was not able to create with its own staff. The
            decision to create financial and technical project
            implementation capacity within the utility itself, with its
            own staff that stayed on past the project's end, was
            vindicated by economy and institution building. Lesson Five:
            The Project demonstrates that a public sector operator can
            improve service quality and operational efficiency without
            the help of private sector operators.
